channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Police officers killed in attack
item.description: Two unarmed female police officers are killed during a "routine" call-out which led to the arrest of a man wanted by Greater Manchester Police.

item.title: Nato curbs Afghan joint patrols
item.description: Nato restricts operations with Afghan forces following a string of deadly attacks on its personnel by rogue Afghan security forces.

item.title: Court injunction over Kate photos
item.description: A court bans a French magazine from re-publishing topless photographs of the Duchess of Cambridge and orders it to hand over the originals.

item.title: Romney taped in Mid-East 'gaffe'
item.description: A new secret video clip emerges of remarks by Republican candidate Mitt Romney, saying the Palestinians are committed to Israel's destruction.

item.title: Manchester United's revenue falls
item.description: Manchester United's annual revenue falls after last season's early elimination from the Champions League, but net profits rise thanks to a tax credit.

item.title: Indefinite jail terms 'unlawful'
item.description: Jailing offenders indefinitely without giving them proper access to rehabilitation courses is a breach of human rights, European judges say.

item.title: Director general states BBC plans
item.description: New BBC director general George Entwistle says he will put programme making and "outstanding creative originality" at the heart of the corporation.

item.title: Capita gets migrant removal job
item.description: The Home Office has given Capita a contract to find 174,000 illegal immigrants, with payments per person removed from the UK, it emerges.

item.title: Loaded gun was 'given to Duggan'
item.description: A loaded handgun was given to Mark Duggan 15 minutes before he was shot dead by police in Tottenham last year, a court hears.

item.title: Three generations killed in fire
item.description: A man is arrested on suspicion of arson after two adults and a child die in a house fire in Cwmbran, Torfaen.

item.title: Biker alive after days in ditch
item.description: The sister of a motorcyclist found alive in ditch almost three days after crashing describes his survival as "a miracle".

item.title: Dark energy camera opens its eyes
item.description: The 570-million-pixel Dark Energy Camera snaps its first image ahead of a survey that aims to unravel one of the Universe's biggest unknowns.

item.title: VIDEO: Zoo breeds world's first Liliger
item.description: A zoo in Siberia has become home to the world's first Liliger a genetic hybrid of two lions and a tiger

item.title: Humphrey to present BT football
item.description: BBC Sport presenter Jake Humphrey to leave the corporation to host BT Vision's football coverage.

item.title: Inflation rate falls back to 2.5%
item.description: The annual rate of inflation in the UK, as measured by the Consumer Prices Index, falls to 2.5% in August after a surprise rise in July.

item.title: Fedex warns of weakening economy
item.description: Global shipping service company Fedex cuts its full-year profit forecast, warning that the global economy is continuing to weaken.

item.title: Hague downplays Nato Afghan move
item.description: Foreign Secretary William Hague insists Nato's decision to scale down joint patrols with Afghan forces will have a "minimal" impact on UK strategy.

item.title: Prince letters to be made public
item.description: An appeal court rules that correspondence between Prince Charles and seven government departments should be published.

item.title: Sweden hails uterus transplants
item.description: Two Swedish women may be able to bear children using the wombs which carried them, doctors say, hailing the world's first mother-daughter uterus transplants.

item.title: Doctor complaints up 23% in year
item.description: The number of complaints made to the General Medical Council about doctors has risen 23% in the past year, the regulator says.

item.title: Watchdog caution on exam changes
item.description: Reforms to examinations for 16-year-olds must be "thought through carefully", the exams watchdog for England warns the government.

item.title: Middle age 'begins at 55 years'
item.description: Research suggests middle age starts much later than previously thought - at age 55.

item.title: Motorola launches Intel handset
item.description: Google's Motorola unit reveals its first Intel-powered handset, promising fast camera technology but not the firm's Chrome browser.

item.title: Microsoft warns on new IE bug
item.description: Microsoft has rushed to issue a patch for a previously unseen bug affecting IE 9 and previous versions of its browser.

item.title: UK seasons data 'needs recorders'
item.description: Wildlife experts are concerned that a decline in the number of people recording plant behaviour could jeopardise long-running data sets.

item.title: Neanderthals 'harvested feathers'
item.description: Our evolutionary cousins the Neanderthals were harvesting feathers from birds to use as personal ornaments, according to a new study.

item.title: Snowman producer John Coates dies
item.description: John Coates, who produced the classic animation film The Snowman, dies of cancer at his home in Kent.

item.title: US poet Louis Simpson dies at 89
item.description: Louis Simpson, a Pulitzer-winning poet whose work explored the darker side of middle-class life in the suburbs, dies at his New York home aged 89.

item.title: South Korean host bars - for women
item.description: Wealthy South Korean women are paying thousands of pounds for the company of handsome young men in so-called "host bars".

item.title: History of the world: Who to leave out?
item.description: Attempting to tell the history of the whole world in one go is a leviathan of a task, and knowing what to leave out is a struggle, says the BBC's Andrew Marr.

item.title: Omission 'disappoints' Pietersen
item.description: Kevin Pietersen is disappointed to have been left out of England's tour to India but wants to return.

item.title: Ba is unhappy with Newcastle role
item.description: Newcastle's Demba Ba "does not understand the management" after starting the 2-2 draw with Everton on the bench.

item.title: Ennis 'should stay in heptathlon'
item.description: Jessica Ennis's coach thinks that she will continue her career in the heptathlon to defend her Olympic title in Rio 2016.

item.title: Missing mountain flyer rescued
item.description: An extreme sports enthusiast from west London who was missing in the Swiss Alps since Saturday is found.

item.title: Car fire death accused remanded
item.description: A 32-year-old woman appears before magistrates charged with conspiracy to murder university graduate Catherine Wells-Burr.

item.title: Reforms 'force blind man to beg'
item.description: A blind man tells a committee of MSPs at Holyrood that he has been forced to beg as a result of UK government welfare reforms.

item.title: Labour chief steps down from post
item.description: The general secretary of the Scottish Labour Party is to step down from after four years in the post, it is confirmed.

item.title: Parties meet on Covenant parade
item.description: The SDLP and Sinn Fein meet the Parades Commission to voice concerns over a controversial march past a Catholic church in north Belfast.

item.title: O'Dowd breached ministerial code
item.description: A report has uncovered several breaches of the code for ministerial appointments when Sinn Fein's Education Minister John O'Dowd filled three seats on the board of the General Teaching Council earlier this year.

item.title: MP thrown out for lie accusation
item.description: An MP is suspended from the House of Commons after claiming that Defence Secretary Philip Hammond was lying over the conflict in Afghanistan.

item.title: 'Badly built' wall killed girl, 3
item.description: A three-year-old girl died when a wall designed by a building company director collapsed on her, a court is told.

item.title: Somalis flee key al-Shabab base
item.description: Thousands of civilians flee as Somali government and African Union forces advance on the al-Shabab stronghold of Kismayo.

item.title: Mass graves found in Kenyan delta
item.description: Two mass graves are discovered in Kenya's coastal Tana Delta region, following deadly ethnic clashes.

item.title: Fresh protests in China-Japan row
item.description: Fresh anti-Japan protests erupt in China over disputed islands amid heightened tension on the anniversary of Japan's invasion of north-east China.

item.title: Wang trial charge 'not contested'
item.description: The ex-police chief at the heart of China's biggest political scandal in years did not contest the charges against him, the court says after a two-day trial.

item.title: Deadly attack on Turkish convoy
item.description: Militants kill seven Turkish soldiers and injure at least 56 more in a rocket attack on a convoy in the east - security officials.

item.title: New EU plan to boost integration
item.description: Eleven EU countries draw up a plan to strengthen the 27-nation bloc, bring it closer to voters and give it more international clout.

item.title: Manhunt after Mexico jailbreak
item.description: More than 130 prisoners are on the run in Mexico after a mass breakout from a jail close to the US border.

item.title: Bolivia's coca production drops
item.description: The United Nations' drugs agency finds the production of coca leaves, the raw ingredient for cocaine, has fallen significantly in Bolivia.

item.title: EU and Iran to hold nuclear talks
item.description: EU foreign affairs chief Catherine Ashton is to meet Iran's nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili in a bid to end the stand-off over its nuclear programme.

item.title: Egypt orders arrest of US Copts
item.description: Cairo seeks the arrest of seven US-based Egyptian Copts and Koran-burning pastor Terry Jones, over a film that sparked widespread Muslim protests.

item.title: Brokerage boss admits $100m fraud
item.description: The founder of US futures broker Peregrine Financial Group pleads guilty to a massive fraud involving 24,000 customers in the US state of Iowa.

item.title: Suu Kyi meets Clinton on US trip
item.description: Burmese pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi is meeting Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in Washington, in a landmark visit to the US.

item.title: In pictures: Manchester police killings
item.description: Manchester officers dead after "routine" call-out

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 September 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 18 September 2012

item.title: Day in pictures: 17 September 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 17 September

item.title: The Scot who shot the American Civil War
item.description: President to prisoners by Alexander Gardner

item.title: In pictures: Murray mania in Dunblane
item.description: Crowds turn out to greet US open champion

item.title: In pictures: Pope Mass in Beirut
item.description: Worshippers attend a seafront mass with Pope

item.title: Week in pictures: 8-14 September 2012
item.description: News photos from the past week

item.title: In pictures: Anti-Islam film protests
item.description: Violent protests continue over film made in US

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are taking part in a series debates before Commons adjourns for the conference season.

item.title: VIDEO: A look at Motorola's new Razr i
item.description: The BBC's Rory Cellan-Jones takes a look at Motorola's Intel-powered smartphone.

item.title: VIDEO: Clean-up divers discover camera
item.description: Divers clearing rubbish from the sea bed off Falmouth in Cornwall process more than 800 family photos on the memory card of a camera retrieved from the water.

item.title: VIDEO: 'I heard gunfire, then a big bang'
item.description: Two female police officers have died during a police operation in Tameside, Greater Manchester, police said.

item.title: VIDEO: Romney secret tape of Florida speech
item.description: A secret recording of US Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has been released in which he appears to condemn millions of Americans who cannot provide for themselves.

item.title: VIDEO: Pink Floyd's former home for sale
item.description: A house in north London where founder members of the band Pink Floyd lived in the 1960s, is to be auctioned

item.title: VIDEO: French court orders photo ban
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have won their legal battle to stop photographs of the Duchess sunbathing topless being published or distributed again within France.

item.title: VIDEO: Mars tweets: Curiosity rover's online persona
item.description: The BBC speaks to the team behind Mars rover Curiosity's irreverant social media presence.

item.title: VIDEO: Argentina's 95-year-old tennis ace
item.description: Argentina's oldest registered tennis player is maintaining a busy training schedule - despite being 95 years of age.

item.title: What adventures are actually left?
item.description: Where is the world's highest unclimbed peak?

item.title: The Ebacc: What's in a name?
item.description: The etymology behind the word baccalaureate

item.title: Murdered goth's story on stage
item.description: Poet Simon Armitage's powerful elegy for murdered goth

item.title: VIDEO: 'Cinema ninjas' silence bad crowds
item.description: The stealth team who pounce on noisy film-goers

item.title: Heathrow expansion: The alternatives
item.description: Six alternatives to a third runway at Heathrow

item.title: Arsenic, cadmium and dying farmers
item.description: Are arsenic and cadmium poisoning Sri Lanka's farmers?

item.title: Pietersen 'must speak through actions'
item.description: Pietersen needs to show England desire

item.title: Publishing's digital switchover
item.description: Death of publishing may have been greatly exaggerated
